name: Compare two fractions with a common denominator or numerator

skills.name: Use inequality notation to order fractions with the same denominators
Use inequality notation to order fractions with the same numerators
Understand comparing fractions is only valid when the two fractions refer to the same whole

explanations.A: This symbol means less than. Using the diagrams, is 2/5 less than 1/5?
explanations.B: As the diagrams show, 2/5 is greater than 1/5 as it 2 parts out of 5 instead of 1 out of 5.
explanations.C: Do the two diagrams show the same amount shaded? Both bars are split into 5 equal parts, but 2/5 means 2 parts, and 1/5 means one part. Which is greater?
explanations.D: We need to denominators to be the same, and they are both 5. The numerators tell us which one is greater - is it 2/5 or 1/5?

explanations.A: This symbol means less than. Using the diagrams, is 3/7 less than 2/7?
explanations.B: As the diagrams show, 3/7 is greater than 2/7 as it 3 parts out of 7 instead of 2 parts out of 7.
explanations.C: Do the two diagrams show the same amount shaded? Both bars are split into 7 equal parts, but 3/7 means 3 parts, and 2/7 means two parts. Which is greater?
explanations.D: We need to denominators to be the same, and they are both 7. The numerators tell us which one is greater - is it 3/7 or 2/7?

explanations.A: 4 is smaller than 8, but look at the scale - the top of the scale is counting in quarters, and the bottom is counting in eighths. If we count 3 jumps along each scale, which one is greater?
explanations.B: The top of the scale is counting in quarters, and the bottom is counting in eighths. 3 jumps along the top scale is further than 3 jumps along the bottom scale, so 3/4 is greater than 3/8. We use the greater than symbol, >
explanations.C: The numerators are equal, so they are each 3 parts, but the denominators are different so they are not the same size parts. Use the number line - the top of the scale is counting in quarters, and the bottom is counting in eighths. Is 3/4 more than 3/8, or less?
explanations.D: It is easier to compare fractions with the same denominator, but look at the scale: the top of the scale is counting in quarters, and the bottom is counting in eighths. Count along to 3/4 on the top, and 3/8 on the bottom. Which one is greater?

explanations.A: The top of the scale is counting in fifths, and the bottom is counting in tenths. 2 jumps along the top scale is further than 2 jumps along the bottom scale, so 2/5 is greater than 2/10 so we have 2/10 < 2/5
explanations.B: 10 is greater than 5, but look at the scale - the top of the scale is counting in fifths, and the bottom is counting in tenths. If we count 2 jumps along each scale, which one is greater?
explanations.C: The numerators are equal, so they are each 2 parts, but the denominators are different so they are not the same size parts. Use the number line - the top of the scale is counting in fifths, and the bottom is counting in tenths. Is 2/10 more than 2/5, or less?
explanations.D: It is easier to compare fractions with the same denominator, but look at the scale: the top of the scale is counting in fifths, and the bottom is counting in tenths. Count along to 2/5 on the top, and 2/10 on the bottom. Which one is greater?

explanations.A: This symbol means less than. Is 11 sevenths less than 9 sevenths?
explanations.B: Both fractions have the same denominator, so we can compare the numerators. 11 sevenths is greater than 9 sevenths.
explanations.C: Both fractions are in sevenths, but is 11 sevenths the same as 9 sevenths?
explanations.D: We need to denominators to be the same, and they are both 7. The numerators tell us which one is greater - is it 11/7 or 9/7?

explanations.A: Both fractions have the same denominator, so we can compare the numerators. 7 eighths is greater than 3 eighths therefore we have 3/8 < 7/8
explanations.B: This symbol means 7/8 is less than 3/8. If we have 7 of something and 3 of the same thing, which would be greater?
explanations.C: Both fractions are in eighths, but is 3 eighths the same as 7 eighths?
explanations.D: We need to denominators to be the same, and they are both 8. The numerators tell us which one is greater - is it 3/8 or 7/8?

explanations.A: 3 is less than 5, a smaller denominator doesn't mean a smaller fraction. Picture a circle split into 3 equal parts, and one split into 5 equal parts. If we shade 2 parts on each circle, which has a greater amount shaded?
explanations.B: Picture a circle split into 3 equal parts, and one split into 5 equal parts. If we shade 2 parts on each circle, shading 2 out of 3 is more of the circle than 2 out of 5, so 2/3 is greater than 2/5. We can also convert both fractions to have the same denominator: 2/3 = 10/15 and 2/5 = 6/15. 10/15 > 6/15.
explanations.C: The fractions have the same numerator, but they are not equal. Picture a circle split into 3 equal parts, and one split into 5 equal parts. If we shade 2 parts of each circle, which one has a greater amount shaded?
explanations.D: We can convert these to have the same denominator to make them easier to compare: 2/3 = ___/15 and 2/5 = __/15. Which is greater?

explanations.A: Picture a circle split into 10 equal parts, and one split into 7 equal parts. If we shade 5 parts on each circle, shading 5 out of 7 is more of the circle than 5 out of 10, so 5/7 is greater than 5/10. We can also convert both fractions to have the same denominator: 5/10 = 35/70 and 5/7 = 50/70 therefore 5/10 < 5/7
explanations.B: 10 is greater than 7 however, a smaller denominator doesn't mean a smaller fraction. Picture a circle split into 10 equal parts, and one split into 7 equal parts. If we shade 5 parts on each circle, which has a greater amount shaded?
explanations.C: The fractions have the same numerator, but they are not equal. Picture a circle split into 10 equal parts, and one split into 7 equal parts. If we shade 5 parts of each circle, which one has a greater amount shaded?
explanations.D: We can convert these to have the same denominator to make them easier to compare: 5/10 = ___/70 and 5/7 = __/70. Which is greater?

explanations.A: 3/8 is a greater fraction than 2/8, but what if Kiera's pizza is small and Luke's is large?
explanations.B: Is 3 eighths less than 2 eighths? Also, what if Kiera's pizza is small and Luke's is large, or vice versa?
explanations.C: Is 3 eighths the same as 2 eighths? Also, what if Kiera's pizza is small and Luke's is large, or vice versa?
explanations.D: 3/8 is a greater fraction than 2/8, but if Kiera saved 3/8 of a tiny pizza and Luke saved 2/8 of a giant pizza, Luke saved more. We can't decide which is bigger unless we know how big the pizzas are.

explanations.A: 3/4 is a greater fraction than 1/4, but what if Lola's drink is small and Fenton's is large?
explanations.B: Is 3 quarters less than 1 quarter? Also, what if Lola's drink is small and Fenton's is large, or vice versa?
explanations.C: Is 1 quarter the same as 3 quarters? Also, what if Lola's drink is small and Fenton's is large, or vice versa?
explanations.D: 3/4 is a greater fraction than 1/4, but if Lola drank 3/4 of a tiny drink and Luke drank 1/4 of a giant drink, Fenton drank more. We can't decide which is bigger unless we know how big the drinks are.
